It's a gross oversimplification to assume that the force is only applied perpendicular to the surfaces colliding. If the relative motion is in a different axis and the surface perpendicular isn't aligned with the centers of gravity of the rotating bodies, you induce forces in different axes and moments that create rotation, adding angular momentum and energy to the equations as well.

What you described would apply to hypothetical point masses but not to any finite rigid bodies.

comment_text:
1D, 2D and 3D are (spatial)

1D: (L)

2D: (L+W)

3D: (L+W+H)

4D, 5D and 6D are 'temporal'

4D: 'length' of (3D)
》one-way flow of time 》

5D:
'length/breadth' of
(3D) 《space-time》

6D:
'length/breadth/depth' of (3D)
《》atemporal《》

"one equation those variables have to satisfy". I see this way too often in descriptions of how things behave, basically saying they do this or that "in order to satisfy some equation" or "because otherwise they would violate some equation or law of physics". And that's just not right. All the equations we have in the field of physics are mathematical DESCRIPTIONS of how the universe works. The universe isn't "following" those laws, the universe isn't doing things "in order to avoid violating" the laws and rules. The universe works the way it works and we DON'T KNOW WHY. All we can do is observe and describe, to the best of our ability, what it does. Mathematics really helps us in doing that. But the mathematics is only describing, not controlling, what happens.

I just wish more lectures and videos and books would make that distinction more clearly and more often.
Super interesting. Does this all mean that brownian motion is deterministic, or the extrapolation is not valid? I am genuinely curious.

Yes, but also no, which anyone trying to implement a physics engine very quickly discovers: while collisions between two bodies can be reduced to 1D and solved really easily, with computers being super great at them, /multiple simultaneous collisions/ between three or more bodies is a 2D problem that can't be reduced to separate 1D solutions. You need to solve it in 2D. Pool/snooker is the absolute classic example: if your cueball strikes two balls at exactly the same time, you better solve the impulse transfer in 2D or you end up with something that looks super, super wrong =P

That reminds me of when I got rear-ended by a Toyota Tundra.

My Dodge Stratus was the stationary object at the light, the Toyota tundra was traveling at about 50mph and did not apply the brakes.

The Tundra collided with us again, sliding us forward another 10 ft and folding the trunk lid through the back window.

The Tundra collided with us a third time and buried itself to my back tires, finally bringing this abbreviated Newton's Cradle to a screeching halt.

The driver offered me any amount of money to let him leave the scene of the accident. I asked you've been drinking, haven't you?

He admitted as much, and his breathalyzer results were just barely over the legal limit.

There were five other vacant lanes he could have swerved into if his excuse of, oh the brakes weren't working, were valid.

There is a subtlety in the scenario of the comming mass transmiting all the moment to the other one so the incoming stops moving: the only possible way for a solution to a differential equation to becoming zero forever after a finite ending time, is by requiring of having a "singular point" in the differential equation so it is possible to brake uniqueness of solutions, allowing to have a piecewise solution that becomes exactly zero after the collision time. This is a issue widely underlook in current physics, and it is understanding that is mathematical impossible to achieve systems with finite ending times without abandon uniqueness of solutions... current models at best vanishes at infinity, but never achieves accurate endings in finite time.

Saying things like "from the universe's perspective" is dangerous because it reifies the concept of a collision. "Collisions" in a physics context are a thought experiment that only exists in our brain, or maybe at best in the Platonic world; they concern unbreakable objects whose properties are only mass and an ability to be associated with a velocity; the video is basically saying "your conception of physical collisions is so simplistic that it's actually 1D". It's a simple Platonic form that loosely and idealistically reflects some parts of the physical world that we can perceive; that Platonic collision is indeed very simple, and the physical world collision is actually insanely complicated.

The video should be titled "most collision problems in high school physics can be represented in 1D"; the video shows 0 awareness of our role as like observers to all of this ~ these thought traps make doing harder physics later sooo much trickier, that is, this kind of thinking makes students tangle up three distinct types of universe: 1. The universe we study in physics through observations and experiments; 2. The universe we imagine in our brains based on our knowledge and experience; and 3. The universe of pure concepts like thought experiments and lines and particles and integers etc.

What if the shape of objects is arbitrary? It just so happens that I have been recently thinking about a general solution for collision problems. There are certainly more than momentum and energy conservations. Take coin toss over a flat surface as an example. Take the instant that the coin collides onto the surface at a single point as t0. How to solve the 6 unknowns: the centroid velocity (ux, uy, uz) and angular speed (ox, oy, oz), for the next time step t0+Dt? It seems that some fictitious displacement at the contacting point is necessary to account for energy conservation or loss. Any idea?

comment_by: 鋼の無神論者：The Fullmetal Atheist
comment_text: For those who like to think in terms of symmetries, in 3D, if you combine translations, rotations, and frame changes (boosts), there are 10 symmetries that are imposed—i.e. ten equations to be satisfied. The variables of a 2->2 scattering problem are the four incoming and outgoing momenta, which account for 4*3=12 variables. So in total the collision depends on only two variables, which you can take to be the incoming energy and relative momentum.

Of course it's all determined. Everything in the universe is determined. But no matter how much you simplify the process, it's still 3D. The collision of 2 balls, as a perfect example, you take one as a 0 point, so you only calculate the other one. You can remove the variety of radial angles of collision and only calculate the bounce angle. And it's a full variety starting from direct collision and bounce back and to ALL the range down to flying forward sliding the side. And it's 2D, even after all the simplifications. So, yeah, to the universe it's very simple. You ignore the error of spin and gravity and other values we haven't discovered yet but even in a model it's just not 1D. Sorry, that's false. You split 2D into 2 1Ds. That's demagogy. Same as saying that ANY number in X system can equal 1 in Y system so ANY division in the universe is a division by 1. It's not how it works, it's just a weird perspective on things that replaces one problem with another.

If vector momentum is conserved in one Galilean reference frame; then same is also conserved in all reference frames; if vector momentum and scalar kinetic energy are conserved in one Galilean reference frame, then  same are also conserved in all reference frames. Choose the reference frame moving along with "centre of mass" velocity, and rotate coordinates so both equal and opposite change in momentum vectors are parallel to the x-axis, and any residual unchanging momenta are parallel to the y-axis. Shifting space and time frame origins to the point of collision fully defines a very nice reference frame where everything is simple: both objects see the y-component of their velocities conserved, and the x-component of their velocities flip sign and multiply by the same constant, where this constant is at least zero in completely inelastic collisions, and at most unity in perfectly elastic ones.

Honestly, I didn't like this video very much.

I must say that this is one of my favourite channels and I really enjoyed every single one of your videos, except this one. In my opinion the problem is oversimplification.

I know that for an ordinary viewer to understand more complicated physics problems (which include basically every video on this channel) , a sacrifice must be made. Often things must be oversimplified, like assuming there is no friction or any kind of lost energy, a perfectly closed system, ignoring some exception to the things being discussed, etc. However there is a moment where if you oversimplify something too much, it either becomes mostly wrong or it just becomes a different "something", only partially related to the original point. I don't know wehre this moment or line is, but I think this is the very first time you managed to cross it.

To quote something: "the outcome of every collision is completely determined" if:
1) we ignore quantum mechanics (that is perfectly fine)
2) we know the mass and velocity of the objects ( still reasonable)
3) we know the amount of kinetic energy lost through heat, sound, etc ( I mean...yes, or we can't determine the outcome)
4) we know the direction of the one "secret" dimension (ummm...sure..)
5) we ignore rotation (to simplify things)
6) we keep in mind that 2D and 3D collisions are "secretly" one dimensional, but this applies for the objects' centers of mass
7) "From a universe's perspective, the outcome of a collusion is uniquely determined" (Absolutely true, but doesn't help us with anything)

Yes, an average person must understand what is going on in the video, but the way I see it, the "ignored" and "assumed" things are just too much. Basically to the point where it sounds to me like "if a meteor falls on Earth and we ignore every other landing location, we can determine that it will hit my house".

Addressing the things you ignored/assumed is something I praise you for, but that doesn't make the video any less silly to me.

We have been trying to realistically simulate collisions with computers for more than 30 years now, and we still have to use hacks, like virtual thickening of surfaces, smoothing out surfaces and their motions etc. When you measure time in discrete intervals collisions are a lot more complicated. In order to know where the "hidden axis" is, you need to know the exact moment of collision, which is near-impossible in a system where time is discrete  and of limited resolution.

Well this description holds only for collisions of two particles that we assume that have no internal structure or have structure but remain bound to move with the same velocity after the collision. If you have a collision that leads to disassociation of one of the particles this description fails since you cannot decompose the collision of the system in two particle collisions since the components of the disassociating particle have to have a potential that initially bound them together into a composite particle. It only works if you suppose that the components are so weakly bound that they can be considered effectively unbound.

If you break down a collision between a mass in motion and a negative mass at rest, and the magnitude of the masses were exactly equal, the math works out to a divide by zero and infinite energy.

For dissimilar masses, this could be imagined as if the larger one was just the smaller one + the difference, as if the two were held together as one, and therefore two masses of the same magnitude, with one negative.

Therefore, no collision involving a hypothetical "negative" mass will result in a rebound, but in a greater-than-atomic explosion, and therefore antimatter has negative mass.

As a somebody who deals with computer simulations of mechanical systems for living, I can assure that simulation of collisions is actually a really complicated topic. If you have a system of multiple interconnected bodies, i.e. you are dealing with multibody system dynamics (that is the scientific keyword here), you can no longer deal with mass and velocity only, but instead you are, usually, solving accelerations from a system of nonlinear differential equations that describe the dynamic force equilibrium of the system. Contacts are treated as external forces, which means you need to be able to solve both the magnitude and the direction of the force, which is not a trivial task when the shape of the object is complex. Also, for contacts to be actually any useful, you need to model the friction forces at the contact points, which is not exactly trivial either, since, among other reasons, many models fail to create any force at zero velocity. In total, this means any contact can need, depending on the models used, 4-8 individually tuned parameters to work.

Of course, if you are making a video game, things can get a lot simpler since accuracy doesn't really matter. But for an accurate simulation that you could use for engineering purposes, things are quite different.

A thought about actual exchanges in real world and the real nature of being a singularity.

Imagine a hollow metal sphere a meter in diameter. If we put a charge on this sphere where exactly is that charge? It is distributed over the entire sphere. And once charged, regardless of where on the sphere I touch I will ground out the entire sphere. So as soon as there is a deeply connected sphere, regardless of size, we begin to have a strange probabilistic distribution of all events.
